tei:div.note: In hagiography: Abai was a Persian Martyr killed by his father, Adorpirozgerd, who later converted to Christianity. He was mentioned in the legend of Saba Pirgushnasp. He was martyred with his mother Astina (Hwarta) and 5000 friends.
In hagiography: Abai of Ḥaḥ was a monk, miracle-worker, and disciple of Simeon of Qartmin. He became abbot of Qartmin and helped to end a plague through his prayers.
In hagiography: ʿAbda was a Bishop of Edessa.
In hagiography: ʿAbdachisia was a martyr from Aphrodisias in Caria.

In hagiography: ʿAbdon and Sennen were two Persian twins martyred in Rome. Their story was contained in the martyrology of Bishop Polychrone, a Bishop of Babylon. They do not figure in Syriac hagiography, but in the Latin tradition they are called Ciccensis adiabenicis victis.

In hagiography: Abel was the first stylite saint of the monastery of Qartmin and was a patron against eye disease and paralysis. According to hagiographic tradition, Philoxenus of Mabbug called upon him for a benediction.
In hagiography: Abimelech was a theologian of the School of Balad who became founder of the martyrion, a secondary institution of the School of Nisibis.
In hagiography: Abraham is a monk of undertmined origins, possibly from the convent of Beth ʿArbin.
In hagiography: Abraham the Penitent (or of Beth Sayyare) was a monk from the family of Awgin and Abraham the Great. He founded a monastery at Zāwīṯā, west of Bamarne.
In hagiography: Abraham the Scribe, also known as Abraham of Shawur, was a monk of Qartmin who cured lepers.
According to The Teaching of Addai, Abshelama (or Barshelama) was an early Bishop of Edessa and a copyist for the apostle Addai.

tei:div.persName: Acyndinus, Anempodistus, Pegasius, Aphtonius, and Elpidiphorus
ACYNDINUS, ANEMPODISTUS, PEGASIUS, APHTONIUS, and ELPIDIPHORUS
tei:div.note: In hagiography: Acyndinus, Anempodistus , Pegasius, Aphtonius, and Elpidiphorus were Greek Christians who died during the reign of Shapur II, according to the legendary Acts describing their martyrdom.
In hagiography: Adorparma was a martyr of Tur Berʿain in Beth Garmai who was commemorated with his brother Mirnarsai and sister Sultana Mahduht.
According to The Teaching of Addai, Aggai was ordained by Addai to be a Bishop of Edessa; he was martyred by the son of King Abgar.

In hagiography: Aḥa the solitary of Resh ʿAyna was a soldier in the Persian army; later he founded a monastery near Nisibis, traveled on extensive pilgrimages, and returned with a piece of the true cross. He converted a village of pagan Armenians.
In hagiography: Alphaeus was a martyr of Caesarea of Palestine who died during the Diocletian persecution and was commemorated with Zachaeus and Romanus.
In hagiography: Amai was a Persian Martyr from the region of Adiabene. She was a daughter of the covenant who was killed with other daughters of the covenant, including Thecla.
In hagiography: ʿAmmi of Ḥaḥ in Ṭur ʿAbdin became the first Bishop of Ṭur ʿAbdin. He was a disciple of Simeon of Qartmin and martyred in Tanzi.
In hagiography: Anastasius the Persian was a soldier in the army of Khusro II. He became a Christian and then a monk after travelling to Jerusalem; he was martyred.

In hagiography: Acyndinus, Anempodistus , Pegasius, Aphtonius, and Elpidiphorus were Greek Christians who died during the reign of shah Shapur II, according to the legendary Acts describing their martyrdom.
In hagiography: Anthony the Qurayshite, born Ruhi, was a convert to Christianity from Islam, the nephew of Harun al-Rashid. He was martyred for refusing to return to Islam.

In hagiography: Acyndinus, Anempodistus , Pegasius, Aphtonius, and Elpidiphorus were Greek Christians who died during the reign of shah Shapur II, according to the legendary Acts describing their martyrdom.
In hagiography: Apollonius was a martyr with Eusebonia mentioned by Rabban Saliba.
In hagiography: ʿAqewshma was a Bishop from the region of Adiabene who was martyred during the persecution of Shapur II and buried by an Armenian princess.

In hagiography: Aquilina was a martyr of Byblos and patron of Jbayl. At the age of twelve, she became a Christian missionary, and she converted pagans by her example and teaching. She was martyred by decapitation.
In hagiography: Archelaus was a Bishop of Ḥarran who debated with Mani.
In hagiography: Athanasius was a monk of Ṭur ʿAbdin.
In hagiography: Athanasius the Cameldriver was Patriarch of Antioch who benefited from the actions of Emperor Heraclius.
In hagiography: Athanasius was a Bishop from Qenneshrin.
In hagiography: Athanasius Sandalaya was the West Syriac Metropolitan of Maypherqaṭ who constructed a monastery at Tel Besme west of Mardin.
In hagiography: Awdisho was an anchorite monk from the area near Arbela who converted the soldier-saint Qardag.
In hagiography: Awdisho was a Bishop and martyr of Kashkar.
In hagiography: Awida was a Persian confessor whose ears and nose were cut off; he had wanted to follow Yasdapnah to martyrdom.

In hagiography: Azad was a deacon of Beth Naggare in Adiabene who was martyred with the priest Jacob during the persecution of Shapur II. The executioner washed his bloody sword in a pool, and the blood desiccated the pool.
In hagiography: Aziza was a monk, born to Egyptian royal pagans, who became a companion of Mar Awgin and established a sanctuary in Zerāni, in the district of Gilu or Hakkari.
According to tradition, Babai was a sister of Sharbel and a convert from paganism. She was martyred in Edessa in the reign of Trajan.
In hagiography: Barbara was a pagan girl converted to Christianity and killed by her father after tortures, perhaps during the Diocletian persecution.
In hagiography Barbʿashmin is commemorated as a Syrian orthodox patriarch.
In hagiography: Barhadbeshabba of Qartmin was a monk and disciple of Samuel of Qartmin.
In hagiography: Barsai was a Bishop of Ḥarran and then Edessa while Ephrem the Syrian lived in Edessa; he built the "Grand Baptistery" there.
In hagiography: Barṣawmā was a Bishop and martyr of the monastery of Hashrai, presumably in Ṭur ʿAbdin.

In hagiography: Bar Ŝewya or Bar Shabba was a solitary and first Bishop of Merv; he was deported from Byzantine territory to Ctesiphon. The sister or wife of Shapor, Shirawan, became Christian and built a church there which Bar Shabba consecrated.

tei:div.persName: Bassus and Suzanne, with Stevin and Longinus
tei:div.note: In hagiography: Bassus and his twin sister Shushān were twin children of a Zoroastrian governor. They were informed about Christianity by a Christian slave. They were baptized by an ascetic named Longinus. They were killed by their father. A monastery was built in their honor near Apamea.

In hagiography: Mar Bawai was commemorated as the Catholicos of the Church of the East from Tella. He was born a Zoroastrian and converted to Christianity through his encounter with a monk called Mar Abda from Qunni. He became a monk and was elected patriarch. His tenure was marked by the efforts of his rival Barsauma to "Nestorianize" the Church of the East. Bawai was killed, perhaps because Barsauma had accused him of being an enemy of the Sasanian empire.
In hagiography: Behnam was a son of the covenant from the Kirkuk region who was stoned under shah Ardashir II.
In hagiography: Benjamin was a hermit and priest from Dara; he was ordained by Barsai of Edessa and travelled to Mount Sinjar. He converted Maʿin; both Benjamin and Maʿin were martyred.
In hagiography: Benjamin was a disciple of Mar Awgin. He travelled to Mount Izla and founded a monastery and school near Mardin>. His vita may be a version of the life of Mar Miha.
In hagiography: Boḥtisho was a deacon and a martyr who assisted Tomarsha in rebuilding churches destroyed under Shapur II. He was martyred under Vahram.
In hagiography: Boḥtizad of Kurke was a saint mentioned in a single East Syriac calendar.

In hagiography: Briḥisho was the brother of Yawnan. They were two brothers from Beth Asa who travelled to a neighboring village to encourage more martyrs. According to tradition, they died during the time of Sapor.
In hagiography: Buṭlāna was a doctor and a martyr. His story was a Syriacized version of the life of Pantaleon.
In hagiography: Rabban Buya was a monk who was from ʿAqra; he had many companions and an anonymous sister who was also venerated as a saint. Her tomb was in Shaqlawa.

In hagiography: Carpus (Qarpos) was the Bishop of Shawaur who was martyred by the Persians; his relics were placed inside a church in Ṭur ʿAbdin that was built by Saliba, the father of Samuel of Qartmin.

In hagiography: Constantine was a Bishop of Laodicea. He was a friend of Severus of Antioch and was present at many of the meetings of the Miaphysites that took place in Constantinople. He was a principal author of the canons of the Miaphysite community from the sixth century.
In hagiography: Cyprian and Justina were martyrs from Antioch who died under the emperor Diocletian.
In hagiography: Cyrus (Qura) was a Bishop of Edessa who transferred the relics of St. Thomas to Edessa in 394.
In hagiography: Cyrus (Qura) was a superior of the monastery of Qartmin. He was a disciple of Samuel of Qartmin.
In hagiography: Cyriacus (Quryaqos) was a disciple of Mar Yareth.

In hagiography: Cyriacus was Bishop of Amida and came from the monastery of Mar Zakka near Edessa. His church was seized by the Chalcedonians, but he restored his churches under Khusro II. He was the author of 30 ecclesiastical canons.
In hagiography: Mar Dodo (Dada) was a saint from Ṭur ʿAbdin and a companion of Mar Awgin. There is a church in Beth Sbirino dedicated to him.

In hagiography: Damian was patriarch of Alexandria. He sent a letter to Jacob Baradaeus hoping for communion between the churches. He visited Antioch but broke from the Patriarch of Antioch, Peter of Callinicus, because of the Tritheist controversy. This schism ended with the patriarchate of Athanasius I Gamolo.

tei:div.persName: Daniel of the Monastery of the Dung Beetles
tei:div.note: In hagiography: Daniel of the Monastery of the Dung Beetles was a refugee from Amida and student of Mar Mattai (his story mirrors the one of Behnam). He established a monastery near that of his teacher, Mar Mattai, with whom he had fled from Amida. The monastery he established was called the monastery of the yellow source. There was a miracle of protective beetles connected to this monastery.

In hagiography: Daniel of Galash was a married man who left his wife to become a monk. He met many ascetics in his life, including Mari and Julien Saba. He visited the portrait of Christ in Edessa. He stayed in a cave with Mari, and then he established a monastery on Mount Aysum. His son Lazarus became his disciple. He built a small monastery in Rome for his father.
In hagiography: Daniel was the Bishop of Edessa. He obtained relics of Severus of Samosata in order to chase demons away from the monks of the monastery of Qenneshre. He wrote a demonology.
In hagiography: Daniel of Qartmin was a monk of Qartmin who was elected Bishop of Qartmin.
In hagiography: Daniel the Stylite was a monk and disciple of Samuel of Qartmin who walked along the Tigris while he went to the land of Qardu (Gazarta).
In hagiography: David was a saint commemorated on the 25 of September by Rabban Saliba.

In hagiography: David of Ḥarran was the Bishop of Ḥarran. He was originally a monk from Qartmin and a relative of Simeon of the Olives. He left all of his precious objects to the monastery of Qartmin, including a manuscript containing a collection of canons.

In hagiography: Demetrianus was commemorated as a Bishop of Antioch. He was deported by the Persians after the conquest of the city in 256. The beginnings of the diocese of Gundishapur were attributed to him.
In hagiography: Denha was a monk of the convent of Qabratha.
In hagiography: Dioscorus was a Patriarch of Alexandria.
In hagiography: Ten brothers of Qartmin are remembered as a group of monks who took part in a fight with villagers from Qartmin over the body of Simeon of Qartmin.
Devotion to Saint Edna is widespread among Maronite Christians. Her name means "ear," and she is invoked for ear infections.

In hagiography: the “Egyptians of Qartmin” were a group of 800 monks from Egypt who were buried at Qartmin. Their legend was connected to the crania in the monastery Qartmin. Eight hundred princes on pilgrimage from Egypt became monks of Qartmin.
In hagiography: Elian was a third-century martyr from Emesa. He was a doctor and was executed by his own father. The Bishop Paul built a church in his honor.
In hagiography: Elijah was an ascetic commemorated by Rabban Saliba.
In hagiography: Elijah was the Bishop of ʿAyn Ward and the first Bishop from the monastery of Simeon of Qartmin. He knew Theodute.

In hagiography: Elijah was the Syrian Orthodox Bishop of Antioch and a convert from the Melkite community. He was a monk from the monastery of Gubba Barraya. He was Bishop of Apamea and later Patriarch of Antioch. He was esteemed by Caliph Al-Walid I who allowed him to build a church.

In hagiography: Elijah of Ḥirta (al-Hira) was a monastic founder from the sixth century. He was an Arab, a Lakhmid, who joined the monastery at Mount Izla and became a disciple of its founder, Abraham. He drove away corrupt monks. He left Mount Izla and established a monastery near Mosul. He was widely venerated by the Arab Christians.
In hagiography: Elijah the Younger of Heliopolis was a martyr from Damascus.
In hagiography: Elisha of Garbiya was a monk of Garbiya near Midyat.
In hagiography: Elisha of Tanhir was commemorated by Rabban Saliba. Little is known about him nor about the location of Tanhir.

In hagiography: Acyndinus, Anempodistus, Pegasius, Aphtonius, and Elpidiphorus were Greek Christians who died during the reign of Shapur II, according to the legendary Acts describing their martyrdom.
In hagiography: See the East Syriac Patriarchs

In hagiography these children were the protagonists of a legend set in the time of the emperor Decius. Eight children of Ephesus were placed in a cave with their dog Qitmir for 190 years. The legend dates to the middle of the fifth century.
In hagiography: Stephen was a superior of a covenant. He was commemorated by Rabban Saliba.
In hagiography: Eugenius and Macarius were priests and martyrs who were decapitated.
In hagiography: Apollonius was a martyr with Eusebonia mentioned by Rabban Saliba.

In hagiography: Eutal (Awtal) was a disciple of Malke, son of Job of Ator, near Mosul. He was also known as "the Arab." He came to Malke for healing, and his tomb was at the monastery of Mar Malke in Ṭur ʿAbdin.

In hagiography: Eutal of Magdala was a pagan who became a Christian in his youth. He abandoned his fiancée and became a monk with Mar Aba in Mopsuestia. He was a miracle-worker who converted thousands of pagans.
In hagiography: Eutychios was a Mesopotamian martyr under Al-Walid. He was also known as “Eustathios,” and he died for refusing to convert to Islam.

In hagiography: Ezekiel was a monk who was born on the same day as the Emperor Constantine the Great. He was a Jew from the tribe of Manasseh who went to Egypt and became a disciple of Mar Awgin. Mar Awgin and his disciples left for the region of Adiabene and Beth Garmai. They went to Maḥoze and baptized the entire city, after they healed the sick. Ezekiel went around the region converting the "Magians." He founded a monastery near Daduq. He ended his life in the region of Kirkuk.
In hagiography: Gabriel of the superior monastery was cited with Mar Abraham as a founder of the superior monastery of Mosul.
In hagiography: Gabriel of Kashkar, also called the "little man," was a monk who founded three monasteries near Maḥoze, Dayr Qunni, and Husra.

In hagiography: Gabrona of Qarta was a Syriac monk under the patriarch Sabrisho. He was from Beth ʿArabaye. He healed the daughter of village leader, Shmona, and he constructed a monastery called Dayr al Qara.
In hagiography: Gamaliel and his son Habib were celebrated in the calendar of Rabban Saliba.

In hagiography: Ganni of Ḥirta or Rabban Haya was a monk from Beth Aramaye. He sold everything he had and gave his possessions to the poor. He became a disciple of Mar Abraham on Mount Izla. Simeon of Taybutha praised his virtues, and this may have inspired the composition of the Liber Castitatis.

In hagiography: Diocletian fell in love with a young woman, Rhipsime, when he saw her picture. She lived a convent with 17 others, and they fled to Armenia. They were captured by the king Tiridates, who tortured and kills Rhipsime, her teacher Gayana, and the other virgins. In the hagiographical account, the king was then turned into a boar. After the king is cured, he and Armenia convert to Christianity.
In hagiography: George of the Greeks was probably called that in order to distinguish him from his predecessor.
In hagiography: George of Ḥarran was a Bishop who came from the monastery of Qartmin. According to his life, during this time, there was much destruction, a flood, and a resurgence of paganism.

In hagiography: Golinduch, the "living martyr," was a Persian princess who became a Christian through the influence of Greek prisoners of war. She was tortured and imprisoned for converting to Christianity, but she was freed by an angel and fled to Nisibis and Mabbug. She was venerated as a living martyr. Her life was preserved in Georgian.

tei:div.persName: Gregory or George, Zwanarse and Yazdapnah
tei:div.note: In hagiography: Gregory or George, Zwanarse, and Yazdapanah were recent East Syriac martyrs.

In hagiography: Guhishtazad was a eunuch martyr at Karka d-Ledan. He was an old man who worked under Shapur II. He was head of the eunuchs and became a Christian, but he lapsed into Zoroastrianism. But the example of Simeon bar Ṣabbaʿe inspired Guhishtazad to become Christian again, and he died a martyr.
In hagiography: Guhishtazad was a eunuch martyr from Karka d-Beth Slokh.
In hagiography: Habib was a disciple of Jacob of Serugh.
In hagiography: Habib of Scetis was a monk who appears among a group of disciples of Mar Awgin. He may have become Bishop of Tanaos or Athens.
In hagiography: Ḥananya of Dayr al-Zaʿfaran was a Syrian Orthodox Bishop of Mardin and Kfartuto. He built a monastery that was named after him on the ruins of the monastery of Slemun.

In hagiography: Helen, the mother of Constantine the Great, is honored in the Syriac church in the hymn to the holy women. Her role in the discovery of the true cross was described in the Syriac narratives. Her feast day is with her son, Constantine.
In hagiography: Heliodorus was a Bishop of Beth Zabdai. 9000 inhabitants of his city were deported to Persia. Many of his community were later martyred, called the martyrs of .
In hagiography: Heraclas of Kafar Sama was a recluse from the village of Midyat.
In hagiography: Hananisho was a Catholicos of the Church of the East.
In hagiography: Hormizd was a martyr of Beth Garmai under Yazdegerd. He had nine friends, and all were converts from Zoroastrianism or had Zoroastrian wives. They were tortured to death.
In hagiography: Hudahwi lived at the time of the Caliph Muʿawiya. Shortly after the Muslim conquest, Hudahwi built the monastery of Beth Hale.

In hagiography: Hwara, son of Theodore lived in the fourth century. He met a monk, Mar Aḥa, who had been taken captive by a crypto-Christian soldier in the Persian army. Aḥa cured Hwara of being mute and in response Hwara became a monk. They established monasteries near Nisibis, where Hwara was the successor of Mar Aḥa.
In hagiography: Hwartha or Astina was a Persian martyr along with her son Abai.
In hagiography: Ia was a woman among the martyrs of Beth Zabdai who converted the wives of some of the Zoroastrians and were tortured and martyred.
In hagiography: Ignatius was the Bishop of Melitene at the end of the tenth century. He built the convent of the Mother of God and a great church of Melitene there.
In hagiography: Isaac was the Bishop of Karka.

In hagiography: The patriarch Isaac became Bishop of Ḥarran by the protection of the governor of the al-Jazira, ʿAbd Allāh. Issac became Patriarch when ʿAbd Allāh became Caliph Al-Mansur. But Al-Mansur had Patriarch Isaac killed and his body thrown into the Euphrates.

In hagiography: Isaac was a Bishop of Edessa. He was named with the approval of the Persians who occupied the city. He refused to give communion to Heraclius on account of the emperor's support of Chalcedon.
In hagiography: Isaiah was an ascetic from Scetis who founded a monastery in Gaza. His life was written by Zachariah the Rhetor. He was a friend of Peter the Egyptian.
In hagiography: Isodore was an abbot and the teacher of Moses the Ethiopian.
In hagiography: Isidore was the Bishop of Ḥarran.
In hagiography: Ishoʿyahb became a monk of Mount Izla. According to legend, he founded a convent in a place where Kurds were supposed to have sacrifices to the demons. He healed many people.
In hagiography: Ishoʿyahb was a Catholicos.
In hagiography: Ishoʿyahb of Arzun was a Patriarch of the Church of the East.
In hagiography: Ishoʿyahb of Gdala was an East Syriac patriarch.

In hagiography: Ishoʿyahb bar Qusre was a monk from a monastery in the region of Adiabene. He founded a church which became the church of Mar Ishaʿya. This became the residence of the metropolitan of Mosul.
In hagiography: Israel of Kashkar was the Bishop of Kashkar and was later elected patriarch, but he was assassinated during the performance of the liturgy in 872.
In hagiography: Ithalaha was a deacon who was martyred with the Bishop Aqewŝma during the persecution of Shapur.

In hagiography: Ithalaha was the Bishop from Edessa who attended the Council of Nicaea. There are literary fragments attributed to him that survive in Armenian. He built the church of Cyrus and Saʿad.
In hagiography: Ithalaha was a pagan priest from Arbela who became a Christian. He was imprisoned with other Persian martyrs, and his ear was cut off. He was decapitated at Beth Lapaṭ.
In hagiography: Jacob was a monk, visionary, and chanter from Beth Garmai. He took over the leadership of a monastery founded by Ishoʿyahb which came to be named after Jacob.
In hagiography: Jacob was a disciple of Jacob Baradaeus who became Bishop of the monastery of Phesilta.
In hagiography: This Jacob the Recluse is mentioned as the founder of a monastery in Siirt together with Mar Hwisa at an unknown date.
In hagiography: John was a Syriac doctor.

tei:div.persName: John the Son of the Carpenters
tei:div.note: In hagiography: John, the son of a joiner, was a Persian Martyr who was killed by his own father. John was tortured with various metallic instruments, and he was ultimately decapitated. His sister was also killed. His relics were collected by Bar Hebraeus.
In hagiography: John III (Hovhannes) of Odzoun was commemorated as a philosopher and Armenian catholicos.

In hagiography: John Bar ʿAbdun was Patriarch of the Syrian Orthodox church, and he had a life fraught with difficulty. He was accused of attracting Chalcedonians to the Syrian Orthodox, and he was brought to Constantinople to be condemned by the Chalcedonians. He was slapped in the church of Hagia Sophia by the Melkite Bishop John of Melitene. He died in exile in Thrace and was honored as a martyr by the Syrian Orthodox.

In hagiography: John the Arab was a monk who originally was from a rich family in Ḥirta. He studied at Nisibis, went to Mount Sinjar, and became a shepherd. He found a place on Mount Izla, and he performed many miracles. Many fought over his relics after his death, and a monastery was built over his remains near the monastery of Mar Awgin.
In hagiography: John the Blue was the Bishop of Ḥirta. He was also known as the young man from Ḥirta.
In hagiography there is mention of a monastery near Qaraqosh named after this John Busnaya.

In hagiography: John the Egyptian or the mourner was the student and compatriot of Mar Awgin. He lived as a solitary on Mount Qardu. He converted the pagans there. He built and was buried at a monastery called Ḥlahlaḥ which was renamed after him.

In hagiography: John the Camel-Driver was commemorated in Thomas of Marga's Book of Governors. In this account, Maran Zha, Bishop of Ḥadita on the Tigris, heard a camel driver singing Syriac chants among the Arab camel drivers. This man, John, had been a Syriac Bishop of the Egyptian diaspora before he was captured by the Bedouins. He was entombed near Ḥadita, but only his habit was found.
In hagiography: John of Ḥarran was commemorated as one of fifty miaphysite Bishops exiled under Justin I in 518.
In hagiography: According to Barsoum, this martyr, John of Kafar Sania, died under Maximinus Hercules.

In hagiography: John of Kamul was born to a pagan family, from a royal Sasanian line. He was converted and tried to convince Shapur his cousin not to persecute Christians. Mar Awgin baptized him under the name of John. He lived in a cave near Mount Gudi and performed many miracles. The monastery of John of Kamul in Gazarta bears his name.
In hagiography: John of Kashkar was born in the region of Kashkar. After a series of abductions, he returned to the monastery of ʿAyn Deqla.
In hagiography: John of Kfone (al-Kfani) was a disciple of Mar Awgin. The monastery of this monk was found south of Zaz in Ṭur ʿAbdin.
In hagiography: John Psaltes was mentioned in the Life of Rabban Samuel of Qartmin. A vision revealed to him the presence of relics in the place called Ḥrbat Tuta.
In hagiography: John of Qartmin or John of Beth Sbirino was a noted paleograph who reestablished the use of estrangelo writing.

In hagiography: John was a priest from Edessa who nourished 12 holy men in a cave. He became friends with Paul, his workman, who was actually a Bishop in disguise. The two lived a life of prayer and spiritual companionship. They travelled to Sinai. Back in Edessa, they interacted with Matthew the eunuch, a woman hiding in a monastery. They travelled to Jerusalem. Paul performed miracles and fled to Nisibis. John found him there, and Paul told him to return to Edessa. Paul died, and John died 8 months later. The story was set in the time of the Bishop Rabbula of Edessa.
In hagiography: Job of Adiabene was a doctor of the Syriac church.
In hagiography: Joseph was a disciple of Narsai. They were martyrs of Beth Garmai.
In hagiography: Joseph was the patriarch of Antioch.
In hagiography: Joseph was a priest and martyr of Arbela.
In hagiography: Karag is an abbot who figures in a Syrian orthodox calendar of Qaraqosh.
In hagiography: Karkus was commemorated as the successor of Ignatius in Antioch, and he was the fourth bishop of the city.
In hagiography: This could be Conon, the Bishop of Tarsus, perhaps consecrated by Jacob Baradaeus in 543.
In hagiography: Kurbur was a Roman magistrate and later a martyr who appeared in the passion of Saint Eleutherios.
In hagiography: Labbe is often identified with the biblical Apostle Thaddeus.
In hagiography: Lazarus was a confessor, a victim of Barsauma of Nisibis. He was also a disciple of Samuel of Qartmin.

In hagiography: Luke was commemorated as a deacon under the Bishop Polychronus. He was decapitated with Parmenius, Helimenas, and Chrysostelus, and another deacon, Mucius, under the emperor Galerius in a place called Cordula (Qardu?).
In hagiography: Macarius was a priest and martyr with Eugene.
In hagiography: Malus was a martyr who could be the same as Miles, Bishop of Susa.
In hagiography: Mamelhta was a virgin and martyr from Beth Garmai. She was known in the Greek martyr Acts as Mamlaha, Mamlahtina, Mazahia or Malpetha.
In hagiography: Mark was a solitary ascetic known from the life of Macarius in the Paradise of the Fathers by Palladius. He was distinguished by his wrestling with the temptations of the flesh.
In hagiography: Mari of Beth Sahde was mentioned two times by Rabban Saliba.

In hagiography: Mari and his wife Martha were Roman martyrs. Husband and wife, they went to Rome on a pilgrimage with their children, Audifax and Abaq, and they were taken in the persecution of Cladius II. Mari and his two sons were decapitated and Martha was drowned.
In hagiography: Mary was one of daughters of the covenant who was martyred with Thecla in Adiabene.
In hagiography: Mary was the sister of Panteleon (Batala) and was commemorated with him.
In hagiography: Mary was commorated as a martyr. She and her brother the priest Jacob were from the village of Tell Salila. She was martyred at Tel Dara under Shapur.
While some hagiographical sources place Mar Awgin in the company of his two sisters, Thecla and Stratonice, Rabban Saliba includes Mary of Scetis in the company of the father of the monks.
In hagiography: Maron was an anchorite.
In hagiography: Maron of ʿAyn Ward was a superior of the monastery of Qartmin and was mentioned in the life of Samuel of Qartmin. He baptized 2000 people in Mesopotamia.

In hagiography: Martha was commorated for being martyred in Rome with her husband, Mari, and children, Audifax and Abaq, while they were on a pilgrimage. They were taken in the persecution of Cladius II. Mari and his two sons were decapitated and Martha was drowned.
In hagiography: Martha was one of daughters of the covenant who was martyred with Thecla in Adiabene.
In hagiography: Mattai (Matta) was born near Amida. He had a marvelous youth and became a monk. A persecution caused him to flee to the Mountain of Alpep, northwest of Mosul.
In hagiography: Maura and her husband Timothy were Egyptian martyrs. They were killed for refusing to burn their copies of Christian scripture.

In hagiography: Maximus and Dometius were brother martyrs. They were brothers, the sons of Valentinian, who fled their father's palace to become monks in Palestine. They went to Egypt and met Macarius.
In hagiography: Metkarkana the Vagabond was commemorated in the Maronite calendar.

In hagiography: Michael the Companion of Angels was a monk linked to Mar Awgin. In some traditions, he was the hagiographer of the Life of Awgin. He was commemorated with other monastic founders in Mesopotamia.
In hagiography: Michael of Tarʿil was commemorated as a disciple of Sabrishoʿ d-Beth Qoqa. He was commemorated at the eponymous monastery of Mar Mikhaʾil of Tarʿil in the region of Adiabene.
In hagiography: Michael and his sister (Shiris?) were martyred outside the gate of Mardin> in a place called the Monastery of the Fish or the Monastery of the Column.
In hagiography: Mihrnarsai, his sister Sultan Mahdok, and their brother Adorparma were among the martyrs of Tur Berʿain.
In hagiography: Moses the Black or the thief was instructed and baptized by Macarius. He was a man of great strength who performed many miracles. He was killed by Bedouins who attacked the monastery.
In hagiography: Mqadashta was the sister of Tarbo and of the Catholicos Simeon.
In hagiography: Muʿawiya was a martyr in Arabia who was thrown to the beasts.
In hagiography: Munyatos was a saint in the Maronite calendar.
In hagiography: The martyrs of Najran, led by Arethas, died in Ḥimyar, condemned by Josef, a Jewish governor.
In hagiography: Narsai, Bishop of Sharqart, and Joseph his disciple, were martyrs of Beth Garmai.
In hagiography: Nestorius of Constantinople was a doctor of the Church of the East.
In hagiography: Nicholas figures in the Maronite calendar.
In hagiography: Nuhra, Syriac for "light," seems to be a translation of the Greek "Phocas" or the Latin "Lumen."
In hagiography: Pāpā was a Bishop of Arzun.
In hagiography: Pāpā was a early patriarch of the Church of the East.
In hagiography: Paul was Bishop of Edessa. He translated the hymns of Severus and revised a Syriac translation of Gregory.

In hagiography: Paul of Nisibis was originally from Prat Maysan. He was a disciple of Mar Aba who signed the synod of Joseph in 554. He was an intermediary between Khusro and Justinian and Justin II. He debated also with Henana over theology of the Church of the East.
In hagiography: Paul the interpreter commented on the Psalms. He might be Paul of Nisibis or Paul of Tella.
In hagiography: Peroz of Beth Lapaṭ was a high born Zoroastrian who became a Christian and was martyred before Bahran V.

In hagiography: Pethion was a Zoroastrian Convert who, with his uncle the monk Yazdin, preached in the region of the lower Zab. His hagiography was connected to that of Anahid's. He was martyred under Yazdegerd II.
In hagiography: Pethion was a monk and a founder of a convent north of the Grand Zab.
In hagiography: Pharkia was a scribe mentioned by Rabban Saliba.
In hagiography: Peter the Patriarch was the seventeenth Bishop of Antioch. He was martyred under the emperor Maximinus.
In hagiography: Peter of Antioch was patriarch of Antioch and reinforced the connections of his church with Alexandria. He fought against "heresies" of Damian of Alexandria.
In hagiography: Plato is known through the Acts of Plato which exist in Greek, Latin and Armenian. He was a Bishop of Ancyra and a martyr under Maximinus.
In hagiography: Polychronus was a Bishop and a martyr. He was probably a deported Greek who became Bishop of Babylonia.

In hagiography: Protonike was purportedly the wife of the emperor Claudius. Her legend was interpolated into The Teaching of Addai. She travelled to Jerusalem, converted to Christianity, and discovered the true cross.
In hagiography: Qashish of Ḥaḥ was a monk mentioned in John of Ephesus' Lives of the Eastern Saints. He went on pilgrimages and helped Theodora to build a hostel for the Miaphysites.
In hagiography: Qawma was a monk and dendrite saint from Beth Garmai. His body did not decay.
In hagiography: Qayyuma of Baz was a monk. He evangelized the region of Baz near Hakkari.
In hagiography: Quna or Conon was the Bishop of Edessa. He set the foundations for the new cathedral of Edessa.

In hagiography: Diocletian fell in love with a young woman, Rhipsime, when he saw her picture. She lived a convent with 17 others, and they fled to Armenia. They were captured by the king Tiridates, who tortured and killed Rhipsime, her teacher Gayana, and the other virgins. Tiridates was turned into a boar. Gregory cured the king, and Armenia converted to Christianity.
In hagiography: Blessed Rifqa Rayyis was a Maronite nun. She was a blind mystic.
In hagiography: Risa or Alexis was the man of God of Edessa. He was born a rich man, but he lived as a beggar in Edessa. He gave all that he had to the poor. He lived at the time of Rabbula.
In hagiography: Ruben was a monk and perhaps a stylite of Qartmin.
In hagiography: Ruhana was identified with Cyriacus, disciple of Euthymia in Palestine from the fifth century.
In hagiography: Saʿad or Saʿdu was Bishop of Edessa.
In hagiography: Saba Gusnasdad was a monk from Beth Lashpar in Southeast Iraq. He was a Zoroastrian Convert who became a monk and converted many Kurdish pagans.
In hagiography: Sabbatius was a solitary monk who lived near the banks of the Euphrates.
In hagiography: Sabellius and Shapira were the parents of the martyr, Talia. They conceived him at the age of 52 years.
In hagiography: Shabra was a child saint commemorated near Midyat.
In hagiography: Shahdost was a Catholicos and a Persian Martyr. He was the successor of Simeon Bar Sabbaʿe.

tei:div.persName: Saints of the Monastery of Mar Abhai
tei:div.note: In hagiography: The saints of the monastery of Mar Abhai were commemorated by Rabban Saliba.

tei:div.persName: Saints of Hrbat Tuta, see John Psaltes (check)
tei:div.note: In hagiography: See John Psaltes.
In hagiography: Shallitha was a common name that means "governor." This probably refers to Artemios, the governor of Egypt under the emperor Julian.

In hagiography: Samuel of Qartmin was from Eshtin near Mardin>. He founded a monastery, Qartmin, with the help of an angel who delineated it for him. His disciple was Simeon of Qartmin. He performed numerous miracles; he brought an end to a plague over Ḥaḥ.
In hagiography: Sanatruq was a frozen martyr in the time of Julian and a companion of Brīhīšō.
In hagiography: Shapira was the wife of Sabellius and the mother of Talia.
In hagiography: Šapor was a frozen martyr in the time of Julian and a companion of Brīhīšō.

tei:div.persName: Shapor and Isaac, Abraham, Ma'ana, Simeon
tei:div.note: In hagiography: Shapur (Šapor) was a Bishop of Niqator who was martyred under Shapur II with Isaac, Maʿna, and Abraham.

In hagiography: “Sarah” was the traditional name for a male martyr’s sister. This pseudonymous usage is derived from Sarah the biblical matriarch and wife of Abraham. One of the most prominent women named "Sarah" in Syriac hagiography was Sara the sister of Behnam. Another is the Sarah associated with Zayna.
In hagiography: Sarah, see also Zayna.
In hagiography: Sharbil became a monk and hermit of the monasteries of Qozhaza, Mayfuq, and Kififane. He lived as a hermit in ʿAnnanya and performed many miracles.

In hagiography: Sasin was a Bishop and a martyr. He was Bishop of Cyzicus on the Sea of Marmara. He was beaten and tortured, but then he was freed with the accession of Constantine the Great. He attended the Council of Nicaea but was later martyred under Constantinus.

In hagiography: Sawrisho was a student of the School of Nisibis. He became a monk of Mount Qardu and performed many miracles. He became a Bishop and played a role in the conversion of Al Numan, the Lakhmid king. Under the influence of Khusro II, he became the Catholicos of the Church of the East.
In hagiography: Sawrisho was a monk who founded the monastery of the martyrs near Tagrit. These monks took refuge in a village during the Muslim conquest.
In hagiography: For Šaʿya, please see Isaiah of Aleppo.
In hagiography: Shayna was identified as “Abramios of Antioch,” a converted Jewish thief.
In hagiography: Seleucus, see Stratonike.
In hagiography: Sergius was a deacon of Huzri. He may have been a writer.
In hagiography: Sergius was the successor of Jacob Baradaeus. He accompanied his teacher to Constantinople where he was received by Theodora.
In hagiography: Sergius of Mount Aride was a monk who founded a monastery known as the “Suspended Monastery.” It became the residence of the Bishops of Balad.
In hagiography: Sergius of Zuqnin is the same as Sergius of Qenneshrin.

In hagiography: Severus, Bishop of Samosata and wonder-worker, was the brother of Athanasius the camel driver. He accompanied his brother to meet Heraclius to return the cross of Jerusalem, and he endured persecution for his Miaphysite position. He lived much of the year as a solitary monk, and he was lame for much of his life after he broke his leg from falling off a horse. He chased away demons.
In hagiography: Severus of Kafar Ze was the superior of the monastery of Qartmin and was mentioned in the Life of Rabban Samuel of Qartmin.
In hagiography: Severus the mathematician was an astronomer from Nisibis who became Bishop of Qenneshrin in 630.
In hagiography: Silvanus of Edessa was the 26th Bishop of Edessa.
In hagiography: Simeon was the Bishop of Edessa who was succeeded by Gabriel.
In hagiography: Simeon was a martyr under Shapor, Bishop of Niqator, during the time of Yazdgerd II.
In hagiography: Simeon may have been the Bishop of Dara who participated in the synod of Mantzikert that sealed union with the Armenian church.
In hagiography: Simeon of Fafo or Papo was a superior of Qartmin mentioned in the Life of Rabban Samuel of Qartmin. He opened the eyes of a blind man before the shah Khusro.
In hagiography: Simeon the Greek was a monk mentioned in the Life of Rabban Samuel of Qartmin.
In hagiography: Simeon Maritime was a monk who performed miracles in the sea. He might be the Saint Simeon for whom the opening of the Orontes was named.
In hagiography: Simeon of Oigona was a saint whose sanctuary was restored in the fifteenth century.
In hagiography: Simeon built a monastery in Qarqafta, between Resh ʿAin and Magdal in the high Gazira.
In hagiography: Simeon the Younger Stylite was from Antioch, the child of John and Martha. He showed signs of holiness already as an infant. He lived on a column on the Miraculous Mountain.

In hagiography: Shirin and her two children were martyrs from Beth Zadoq. She was baking bread when she learned of 12000 martyrs under Yazdegerd II. She took herself and her children before the governor and confessed her Christian faith to him. She and her children were decapitated.
In hagiography: Shirin was born a Zoroastrian but converted to Christianity. She faced great hardship from her family on account of this. She was imprisoned and executed.

In hagiography: Shlemun the mourner was Bishop of Ḥaditha on the Tigris towards the middle of the VIII century. He converted Muslims. He was beaten for this and made to shave his beard and head. He had a rivalry with Isa ibn Shalupa, the head of doctors of the caliph, concerning taxes imposed on Christians by Muslim authorities. He opposed the election of Patriarch Timothy in 780. He died at the monastery of Mar Ahrun near Balad.
In hagiography: Shmona was a martyr from Edessa who was mentioned in the Acts of the Edessa martyrs with Guria.

In hagiography: Shenoute of Atripe was an Egyptian monk and a superior of the White monastery. He enforced a strict interpretation of the rule of Pachomius. He often left his monastery to fight pagans and heretics. There was a Syriac version of his life.
In hagiography: Sophenian was from the region south of Armenia between the Tigris and the Euphrates. He was a superior of the monastery of Qartmin.
In hagiography: Stratonike was the sister of Mar Awgin, along with Thecla. She was mentioned in the hymns on the Holy Women.

In hagiography: Bassus and his twin Suzanna were twin children of a Zoroastrian governor. They were informed about Christianity by a Christian slave. They were baptized by an ascetic named Longinus. They were killed by their father. A monastery was erected in their honor near Apamea.
In hagiography: Saint Theodore was mentioned in the calendar of Qaraqos.

In hagiography: Theodore of Kashkar was a monk who founded his own school outside of the city. When he was older, he retired in solitude and grew wild herbs. He went to the caliph Umar I ibn al Hattab to obtain an exemption for priests and deacons.
In hagiography: Theodosius was a Bishop, perhaps a monk from Qartmin, who died in the oven along with those who were martyred with him.
In hagiography: Thomas was a Bishop and confessor.
In hagiography: Thomas was a disciple of Simeon of the Olives.
In hagiography: Thomas was a stylite saint of Tella.
In hagiography: Thuthaël was a martyr of Edessa who was commemorated with Sharbel.
In hagiography: Thuthaël was a stylite and disciple of Samuel of Qartmin.
In hagiography: Timothy was the Bishop of Edessa. He participated in a synod in Mabbug that elected the deacon George.

In hagiography: Timothy of Alexandria, also known as Aelurus or the Cat because of his extreme thinness, was the patriarch of Alexandria. He was exiled in 460 but reclaimed his see in 475. He was active in fighting against the Council of Chalcedon.
In hagiography: Rabban Yawnan was a famous monk of the monastery of Bar Tura. This monastery suffered from attacks during the Muslim invasion.

In hagiography: Yawnān Nūkhriṭā (the "stranger") was born Yuwanis in a noble family of the lineage of Constantine the Great. He became a disciple of Mar Awgin. He changed his name to Yawnan. He journeyed to Jerusalem and Sqete. Mar Awgin sent him to the land of the Persians, and he founded the monastery at Peroz Shapur on the Euphrates (Al-Anbar).
In hagiography: Yawnan was a Bishop of Ḥaḥ.
In hagiography: Yazdanduht was a holy woman of Arbela who, in 345, in the royal cities, took care of 120 martyrs of Adiabene (111 priests and deacons; nine virgins), She then buried them.
In hagiography: Yazdapnah was the Bishop of Kashkar. He was attested under the patriarch Mar Emmeh (646-49) and his contemporary was Rabban Theodore.
In hagiography: Yazdapnah was a martyr with Gregory.

In hagiography: Yazdin was an anchorite from the fifth century. He converted to Christianity along with his brother, Dadisho. Dadisho's son, Pethion, became a martyr and converted Adorhormizd and his daughter Anahid. He was from Iran.
In hagiography: Christine or Yazdoi from Karka de Bath Slokh was the daughter of a Zoroastrian governor who was martyred after her marriage.

In hagiography: Yozadaq was a monk and a disciple of Bar Edta and a companion of Rabban Hormizd on Mount Resa. He built a monastery. He wrote letters to Rabban Isiʿyaw. He also wrote a letter to one of his disciples in which he thanked him for a copy of the works of Isaac of Nineveh.

In hagiography: Zakka was probably a disciple of Mar Mattai, and thus he was connected with the saints of Mosul. Before becoming the successor of Matta, he inhabited a small cell at the end of the valley of Mar Abraham. He was also connected with the legend of Behnam.

In hagiography: Zayna, a Bishop and martyr, and his sister Sarah, were a brother and sister pair similar to Behnam and Sara. Their cult in Tagrit was a rival to that of Behnam and Sara at Mar Mattai. Zayna was the son of Ator, a king. He became a monk and Bishop. Their story was elaborate and involved dragons, healed kings, profitable caravans, and supernatural senses. The cult of Zayna and Sarah was very popular in Qaraqosh.

tei:div.persName: Disciple of an elder of Scetis

tei:div.note: In hagiography: Constantine was a Bishop of Edessa commemorated by Rabban Saliba.
In hagiography: Constantine was a Bishop of Edessa commemorated by Rabban Saliba.
In hagiography: Cyrus (Qura) of Edessa closed the School of the Persians and expelled its members in 489 with the help of the Emperor Zeno.
In hagiography: Lazarus of Zagug lived near the famous monastery of Zazug around Alexandria where Severus of Antioch died.
In hagiography: Lazarus was a Bishop of Ṭur ʿAbdin, who was attested in a synod of 735.
In hagiography: Lazarus of Habsenas is a saint after whom Simeon of the Olives named a monastery.

tei:div.persName: Monk of the convent of Rabban Hormizd
Saint (one who spent 25 years in a cave)
